document.masterDocTitle: From the subantarctic to the subtropics: a revision of the Davacaridae Kethley, 1977 (Acari: Trigynaspida: Mesostigmata) with the description of a new genus and three new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: From the subantarctic to the subtropics: a revision of the Davacaridae Kethley, 1977 (Acari: Trigynaspida: Mesostigmata) with the description of a new genus and three new species

bibRefCitation.author: KETHLEY, J. B.
bibRefCitation.refString: KETHLEY, J. B., 1977, A review of the higher categories of Trigynaspida (Acari: Parasitiformes), International Journal of Acarology, 3, 129 - 149.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Trigynaspine Mesostigmata with setae av4 , pv4 present on intercalary sclerite on tarsus IV; trochanter I with six setae; palp genu with six setae; chelicerae chelate-serrate, pilus dentilis absent, movable digits ( figures 1A, B , 4C , 8C , 9C ) with strongly fimbriate ventral excrescence, serrate paraxial membrane, and finger-like process arising antiaxially; tritosternal laciniae fused basally; tectum denticulate, without median keel; adults with two to four pairs of large opisthosomal gland openings ( figures 2C, D , 4A , 7A , 9A ). Dorsum of deutonymphs ( figure 6D ) and adults ( figures 2C , 4A , 7A , 9A ) with four major shields, each usually surrounded by leathery cuticle in fully sclerotized adults ( figure 2C ). Postanal seta present in larva and nymphs, absent in adults. Claws on legs I large, sessile. Chaetotaxy of legs I-II-III-IV: coxae: 2-2-2-1; trochanters: 6-5-5-[5, 6]; femora: 12-10-7-8; genua: 11-11-11-10; tibiae: 13-10-10-10, respectively. Palpal chaetotaxy: trochanter, femur, genu, tibia: 2-5-6-14, respectively; palp apotele with three tines. Females with six pairs of intercoxal setae, welldeveloped mesogynial shield, and usually with endogynial complex. Males with five to six pairs of intercoxal setae (z/2 genital valve seta), subcircular and

Davacarus lindquisti
, n. sp. , subcapitulum and tritosternum.

subSubSection.paragraph: crescent-shaped genital valves between coxae III–IV; chelicerae not obviously modified for sperm transfer; gnathotectum sometimes sexually dimorphic ( figure 8B versus 8E).

Remarks. As noted by Hunter (1970) , species of
Davacarus
appear to have only two dorsal shields because of a pigmented leathery sclerotization of the cuticle around the primary shields. In teneral adults, the true limits of the dorsal shields are readily apparent, but as the new adult hardens the shields appear to grow and coalesce as a dark, thickened, micropunctate band forms around each shield. The same process occurs ventrally and results in a wellprotected mite. This is especially true in the new genus described below, where the leathery secondary sclerotization results in the appearance of a holodorsal shield ( figure 2C ).

caption.paragraph:
FIG. 3. Endogynial complexes of (A)
Davacarus gressetti Hunter

Davacarus reginaldi
, n. sp. ; (C)

, n. sp.

FIG. 4.
Acanthodavacarus klompeni

FIG. 5.
Acanthodavacarus klompeni
, n. sp. (A) Venter of female; (B) venter of male. Scale bar: 100 M m.

subSubSection.paragraph: The results of a cladistic analysis supported the monophyly of Davacaridae and its division into two clades, represented by a new species and genus described below, and three species in the type genus that share the loss of the anterior genital shield (pregenital shield) and its apparent conversion into a complex endogynium with a pair of punctate processes ( figure 3 ). The presence of four primary dorsal shields is a juvenile character and the retention of these shields in the adult represents a synapomorphy of the family that separates Davacaridae from all other Trigynaspida. Other distinctive synapomorphies of the family are a thick, finger-like paraxial process that moulds to the cheliceral teeth ( figures 1A, B , 4C , 8C , 9C ), the form of the single ventral cheliceral excrescence, and the enlarged opisthosomal gland openings ( figures 2C, D , 4A , 7A , 9A ). Two genera and four species are known, including the new genus and three new species described below.

caption.paragraph:
FIG. 6.
Acanthodavacarus klompeni
, n. sp. (A) Dorsum of larva; (B) venter of larva; (C) dorsum of protonymph; (D) dorsum of deutonymph. Scale bar: 100 M m.

subSubSection.paragraph: 1 Genital opening of female covered by three shields ( figures 2B , 8A , 10A ), pregenital

shield absent; seta st4 laterad other sternal setae; endogynium ( figure 3 ) with punctate regions; dorsal setae acuminate, simple to barbed ( figures 7A , 9A ); four pairs of enlarged opisthosomal glands, posterior glands sessile..
Davacarus Hunter
(2)

– Genital opening of female with four shields ( figures 2A , 5A ), including pregenital shield with punctae and a pair of setae ( st4 ); complex endogynium absent; dorsal setae short and densely pilose ( figure 4A ); two pairs of large lateral opisthosomal glands on short horn-like processes ( figures 2C, D , 4A )......................
Acanthodavacarus
n. g.
klompeni
n. sp.
2 Setae on dorsal shields relatively long ( figures 7A , 9A ), most extending well beyond
insertion of next seta in series; opening of anteriormost opisthosomal gland in soft cuticle; fixed digit with § 12 teeth; male genital valves with a pair of setae 3

– Setae on dorsal shields relatively short, most just reaching insertion of next seta in series; anterior opisthosomal gland on small platelet with a pair of pores; fixed digit with ƒ 10 teeth; male genital valves nude...
Davacarus gressetti Hunter

seven setae; pygidial shield with eight setae; fleshy, fimbriated process present behind coxa IV ( figure 7B ); sternal setae st1 and st4 of female in soft cuticle ( figure 8A ); movable digit with six to eight teeth ( figure 8C, F ); internal malae

barbed ( figure 8D )............
Davacarus reginaldi
n. sp.

– Podonotal shield reticulate laterally, smoothly micropunctate medially ( figure 9A ); mesonotal shields each with six setae; pygidial shield with seven setae; no fleshy fimbriated process at coxa IV; sternal seta st1 on small platelet, st4 on sternal shield with st2–3 ( figure 10A ); movable digit with 15–16 teeth ( figure 9C ); internal malae simple ( figure 9D )..........
Davacarus lindquisti
n. sp.
